metadata.title: People are addicted to their phones.
metadata.subtitle: LEARN

content.raw: Any normal person, at any normal time, is more likely to be using their phone than doing anything else. They are either scrolling, tapping, watching, or playing, digital content on a piece of glass. This time is spent with no avail of life progress or succession. Sometimes too distracted to even look up when somebody is talking, or when walking on the street, or even when driving. Phones, such an important revolutionary tool, have become a part of society's downfall.

I want to explore why this addition occurs. What causes people to prioritize liking a post over face to face contact? Why do we hide from our feelings by scrolling through short 30 second pieces of content? And finally, what can we do to stop this addiction?
Take a look at your screen time.

How many hours do you use your phone? One? Two? The national average in the United States is three hours and fifteen minutes. Three hours, is a quarter of your waking time, spent scrolling. That's a lot of time. And that's just the average. Some people spend up to 10 hours a day on their phone. That's almost half of their day.
